courses.description: Current topics illustrating important research field in materials science will be discussed. Topics covered will include: energy materials, biomaterials, and computational material science. The course provides an introduction to the background concept, physical principles and applications of the relevant material systems.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Physics, MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg or MPhil-PhD Physics
courses.learning_outcomes: Students at the end of the course are expected to have gained an appreciation of the fundamental concepts as well as the state of art methodologies in frontiers of materials research. They are expected to have gained the ability to operationalize these concepts in precise frameworks, and to have the ability to pursue these topics in further depth beyond this course. Some of the material will have to be learnt by the student on their own, and through this activity students will develop the capability and habit of self-directed learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
(1) Energy materials:

(a) Materials for light harvesting and applications: Fundamental concepts of photovoltaics; Principles of solar cell operation and efficiencies; Semiconductor materials for light harvesting and photovoltaic devices; Defects and doping of semiconducting materials for energy applications, including basic concepts of defects in semiconductors and defect engineering (optional); Light harvesting enhancement and plasmonic materials; Material requirement and device configurations of single junction device and tandem cells; Different generations of solar cell devices and their working principles, including crystalline silicon solar cells, thin film solar cells, organic, dye-sensitized cells and hybrid cells

(b) Materials for energy storage and applications: General introduction of battery industry and its advances; Highlight on Li-ion batteries (LiBs): Working principles (e.g., mechanisms of Li-ion intercalation and deintercalation); basic concepts and parameters of LiBs (e.g., capacity, energy density, power density, rate capacity, and cyclability); Common cathode and anode materials and their electrochemical properties; Ionic conductors; Materials Issues and safety aspects in sustainable Li-ion Batteries; State of art batteries beyond conventional LiBs.

(2) Biomaterials: Background concepts on biological systems (e.g., protein, cell, tissue); Classes of materials for medical applications including metals, polymer, hydrogel, ceramics, and biologically functional materials; Properties of biomaterials and characterizations; Interaction between biomaterials and biological systems (e.g., inflammation, and immune response etc.); Toxicology evaluation of the biomaterials; Applications of biomaterials (e.g., drug delivery, tissue engineering)
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Tom Markvart & Luis Castaner, “Practical handbook of photovoltaics: fundamentals and applications” Elsevier, 2007
2. S.R. Wenham, M.A. Green, M.E. Watt, R. Corkish “Applied Photovoltaic” second edition, Earthscan, 2007
3. M.A. Green “Third Generation Photovoltaics Advanced Solar Energy Conversion” Springer, 2003
4. Antonio Luque “Handbook of Photovoltaic Science and Engineering” Wiley, 2003
5. S. H. Wei, Computational Materials Science Volume 30, Issues 3–4, August 2004, Pages 337–348
6. Zhu and Wei, “Overcoming doping bottleneck by using surfactant and strain”, Frontiers of Materials Science December 2011, Volume 5, Issue 4, pp 335-341
7. Tigran V. Shahbazyan; Mark I. Stockman (eds.), “Plasmonics: Theory and Applications” 2013.
8. Stefan A. Maier, “Plasmonics: Fundamentals and Applications”. New York, Springer. 2007.
9. Stefan Enoch, Nicolas Bonod (eds.), “Plasmonics: From Basics to Advanced Topics” Berlin, Heidelberg: Springer, 2012.
10. Matthew Pelton, Garnett Bryant, “Introduction to Metal-Nanoparticle Plasmonics”, New Jersey: John Wiley & Sons, Inc. 2013
11. Vincenzo Giannini, Antonio I. Fernández-Domínguez, Susannah C. Heck, Stefan, A. Maier, “Plasmonic Nanoantennas: Fundamentals and Their Use in Controlling the Radiative Properties of Nanoemitters”. Chemical Reviews 2011, 111, 3888-3912.
12. Seth M. Morton, Daniel W. Silverstein, Lasse Jensen, “Theoretical Studies of Plasmonics using Electronic Structure Methods” Chemical Reviews 2011, 111, 3962-3994.
13. Lukas Novotny, Niek van Hulst, Antennas for Light. Nature Photonics 2011, 5, 83-90.
14. Jon A. Schuller, Edward S. Barnard, Wenshan Cai, Young Chul Jun, Justin S. White, Mark l. Brongersma, “Plasmonics for Extreme Light Concentration and Manipulation”. Nature Materials 2010, 9, 193-204.
15. Dmitri K. Gramotnev, Sergey I. Bozhevolnyi, “Plasmonics beyond the Diffraction Limit”. Nature Photonics 2010, 4, 83-91.
16. Harry A. Atwater, Albert Polman,” Plasmonics for Improved Photovoltaic Devices”. Nature Materials 2010, 9, 205-213.
17. Allen J. Bard, Larry R. Faulkner, “Electrochemical Methods: Fundamentals and Applications”, 2nd Edition
Wiley, 2001
18. Masaki Yoshio, Ralph J. Brodd, Akiya Kozawa, “Lithium-Ion Batteries: Science and Technologies”, Springer, 2009
19. Hyun Deog Yoo, Elena Markevich, Gregory Salitra, Daniel Sharon and Doron Aurbach, “On the challenge of developing advanced technologies for electrochemical energy storage and conversion” Materials Today, Volume 17, Number 3, 2014
(General introduction of batteries)
20. John B. Goodenough and Kyu-Sung Park, “The Li-Ion Rechargeable Battery: A Perspective”, J. Am. Chem. Soc., 2013, 135 (4), pp 1167–1176 (battery chemistry)
21. Vinodkumar Etacheri, Rotem Marom, Ran Elazari, Gregory Salitra and Doron Aurbach, “Challenges in the development of advanced Li-ion batteries: a review”, Energy Environ. Sci., 2011,4, 3243-3262 (electrode materials and their electrochemical properties)
22. Rotem Marom, S. Francis Amalraj, Nicole Leifer, David Jacob and Doron Aurbach “A review of advanced and practical lithium battery materials”, J. Mater. Chem., 2011, 21, 9938 (electrode materials and ionic conductors)
23. Peter G. Bruce, Stefan A. Freunberger, Laurence J. Hardwick, and Jean-Marie Tarascon, “Li–O2 and Li–S batteries with high energy storage” NATURE MATERIALS, VOL 11, 2012, 19-29 (state of art battery solution beyond conventional LiBs)
24. Buddy D. Ratner, Allan S. Hoffman, Frederick J. Schoen, Jack E. Lemons, “Biomaterials Science, Third Edition: An Introduction to Materials in Medicine” Academic Press, 2013
25. Johnna S. Temenoff (Author), Antonios G. Mikos, “Biomaterials: The Intersection of Biology and Materials Science” Prentice Hall, 2008

courses.subject: MSEG
courses.title: Topics in Advanced Materials Research IV (Electron Microscopy: Principles, Techniques and Analysis)
courses.description: This course is intended to provide basics of electron microscopy. Topics include: group theory and basics of crystal symmetry; electron diffraction and interpretation of crystal symmetry; wave optics and imaging principle of electron microscopy; high-resolution transmission electron microscopy; analytical electron energy microscopy; and laboratory demonstration of specific topics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg; For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics
courses.recommended_readings:
1. “Transmission Electron microscopy”, D. B. Williams and C. B. Carter, Plenum Press, New York and London
2. “Electron Microscopy of Thin Crystals” By P. Hirsch et al., Krieger Publishing Company, Malabar, Florida
3. “Transmission Electron Microscopy—Physics of image formation and microanalysis” L. Reimer, Springer-Verlag

courses.subject: MSEG
courses.title: Surface Science
courses.description: This course serves as an introduction to surface science. Major topics are: vacuum technology, electron-surface interactions, photon-surface interactions, ion-surface interactions, scanning probe microscopy and case studies in surface science.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg; For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To master the basics principles of vacuum and its significance in surface science
2. To master the physical principles involved in major surface characterization techniques including x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Auger electron spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and scanning tunneing microscopy/atomic force microscopy
3. To master major surface characterization techniques experimentally and understand how to achieve the optimum condition for experiments.
4. To apply the corresponding techniques in material anlysis and be able to select the appropriate techniques for specific properties measurement
5. To be able to carry out correct data interpretation using surface characterization techniques
6. To practice problem solving and team collaboration in small projects
7. To practice presentation skills on scientific interpretation of the surface characterization results.
courses.course_syllabus:
Vacuum Technology
Photoelectron Spectroscopy
Auger Electron Spectroscopy
Scanning Electron Microscopy
Scanning Probe Microscopy

courses.subject: MSEG
courses.title: Guided Study
courses.description: To carry out reading and presentation assignments to enhance learning and research skill.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To master advanced concepts and major theories of assigned topics.
2. To develop ability in self-learning.
courses.course_syllabus: Research work assigned by thesis supervisor.
courses.required_readings: Journal articles and other research materials assigned by individual supervisors.

courses.subject: MSEG
courses.title: Thesis Research
courses.description: In this course, a student is required to meet with his/her supervisor regularly who provides necessary guidance and supervision to write up a thesis and monitors the student's academic progress.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are expected to develop research skills, including theory and/or laboratory studies and data analysis as related to the students' thesis research.
courses.course_syllabus: Research work assigned by thesis supervisor.
courses.required_readings: Journal articles and other research materials assigned by individual supervisors.
